docs.lead_paragraph: NEW YORK lawmakers are understandably concerned about the runaway cost of Medicaid. With nearly four million people receiving benefits, New York's program is the largest and most costly in the country. And the program is rife with fraud and abuse. According to James Mehmet, former investigator for the Health Department's fraud and abuse office in New York City, some 40 percent of all claims in the state are considered questionable, costing taxpayers as much as $18 billion a year.
docs.snippet: New York's Medicaid program is big, bloated and broken.

docs.lead_paragraph: Personal Accounts Numbers don't lie, but they can tell different stories. America's 4.9 percent unemployment rate in August was near historic lows, for example, but last year wages for the average American worker (adjusted for inflation) fell for the first time in a decade. Gross domestic product grew by 3.3 percent last quarter -- the 15th quarterly increase in a row -- but median household income remains below what it was in 1999. Corporate profits grew by 6.9 percent in the second quarter, but bankruptcy filings were also 12 percent higher than in the same period last year, when household debt reached a record high. And so on. But how, in this era of killer hurricanes and housing bubbles, are Americans actually doing? To get a more human answer to that question, the Op-Ed page asked writers in different parts of the country to provide snapshots of their local economies over the next year. Here are their initial dispatches.

In the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina, we have an opportunity to construct something far more important than higher levees -- a national health care system that looks less like a tightrope and more like a safety net. A dozen years after Bill Clinton's health reform efforts were destroyed by the insurance industry's duplicity, it's worth trying again. The health care system is steadily becoming more gummed up in ways that are impossible to hide.
docs.snippet: In the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina, we have an opportunity to construct a national health care system that looks less like a tightrope and more like a safety net.

docs.lead_paragraph: If recent history is any guide, Eliot Spitzer's chances of becoming governor of New York next year are greatly enhanced by the presence of the words ''attorney general'' on his résumé. Since 2002, Democrats nationwide have won 18 open seats for governor or senator. Six of the winners had served either as state attorney general or United States attorney. Two others were prosecutors before entering politics. Not even mayors or congressmen were as well represented.

headline.main: Spitzerism: Is a prosecutor's zeal what the Democrats need?

docs.snippet: Is a prosecutor's zeal what the Democrats need?

multimedia.credit: The story of Eliot Spitzer's experience as New York attorney general may contain an approach that Democrats around the country can mine for political success.
multimedia.caption: A Prosecutor's Zeal

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: The story of Eliot Spitzer's experience as New York attorney general may contain an approach that Democrats around the country can mine for political success.

docs.lead_paragraph: On a brilliant Sunday afternoon last month, Mayor Michael Bloomberg came to Lenox Avenue in Harlem to march in the annual African-American Day Parade. As he and his supporters prepared to step out into the street, a phalanx of marchers led by Fernando Ferrer, Bloomberg's Democratic challenger in the coming mayoral election, appeared behind him. Ferrer was flanked by leading black figures, including the Rev. Al Sharpton, gadfly and provocateur. Suddenly the rivets began to pop on the mayor's smoothly machined schedule. The parade organizer bizarrely, but very insistently, demanded that Bloomberg march alongside his own challenger. The mayor, flushed, said, ''I'm here to march with my friends.'' Harlem is not friendly territory for a white Republican officeholder. Was there a racial subtext? It wasn't clear. The crowd grew denser and more turbulent, squeezing Bloomberg and his entourage to the edge of the street. ''Run, Freddy, run!'' came the cry from behind. The mayor, throttled, sidelined, stood with his arms crossed for five, six, seven minutes and said. . .nothing. He said absolutely nothing, and the incident, the nonincident, melted away.
docs.snippet: Politics in an era of anticlimax.

docs.lead_paragraph: What is the first thing you will grab from your home if your house floods, catches on fire or comes tumbling down in an earthquake? Family photos? The pets? The Hummel figurines? It probably will not be your financial and medical records, the very things you will need to rebuild your life after a disaster. If you are like most people, you have documents stashed in various places throughout your home, perhaps some under lock and key. And with your mind racing as danger hits, you are not going to have the time or wherewithal to figure out which ones you need.

headline.main: How to Prepare for One Really Quick Getaway

docs.snippet: New technology is making storage of financial and medical records less odious, and surprisingly, it is not that expensive.

docs.lead_paragraph: This week, officials announced the takeover of New York's largest health insurer in a deal that will bring the state a huge windfall. All told, the state stands to collect billions for having allowed the insurer, once known as Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, to become a profit-making company, which is now to be acquired by WellPoint, the nation's largest health insurer. The projected total, $4.8 billion, is nearly five times what state officials originally predicted they would net from the conversion, and a much-needed bonanza for the state budget. But over the years the deal has also paid political dividends and, perhaps inevitably, wound up producing contracts for companies with ties to the Pataki administration and the Republican Party.

headline.main: In Conversion Of Insurer, Contracts Go To Insiders

docs.lead_paragraph: THERE is a saying among consumer advocates regarding homeowner's insurance: ''Use it and lose it.'' It is not a phrase that insurance companies are particularly fond of. But it sums up how all too many people feel about their homeowner's insurance: if you decide to make a claim, you are in danger of being dropped.

headline.main: The Peace of Mind of Home Insurance, Unless You Use It

docs.snippet: There is a saying among consumer advocates regarding homeowner's insurance: "Use it and lose it."

docs.lead_paragraph: HURRICANE RITA wrought perhaps $60 billion in damage to Texas and Louisiana last weekend, according to one estimate, easily enough to make it one of the 10 costliest storms ever. But after the extraordinary destructiveness of Hurricane Katrina less than a month earlier, it seemed almost like a blessing that it wasn't worse.

headline.main: A Storm Leaves Higher Heating Bills in Its Wake

docs.snippet: Hurricane Rita raked over a part of the Gulf Coast's energy industry that had largely escaped damage from Katrina, extending and perhaps worsening shortages of gasoline and heating oil.
